Loving your videos! One nitpick on this one, though: coelacanths really aren't "simple fish". If anything, they're some of the more complex - along with the lungfish, they're the only extant fish possessing the developed internal limb skeletons that in tetrapods evolved into legs and feet. The simplest fish lack jaws, paired fins, and bones: the only evolutionarily "simple" fish living today are the lampreys and hagfish.

The takahē, one of New Zealand's many flightless birds, was first known to science through fossils, with the birds presumed to have gone extinct before European arrival (similar to the moa). However, in 1849, the first live specimen was discovered by a group of sealers... who promptly ate the bird. Three more live specimens were found between 1849 and 1898, but when no more were found after this the species was once again declared extinct.
This is when our story gets really exciting, because in 1948 live takahē were rediscovered for the second time strutting around an extremely remote valley in the South Island!!!!!! After decades of painstaking conservation work, the takahē population is now recovering at a slow but steady rate, so here's to possibly the worlds only bird to have gone extinct twice and lived to tell the tail!!! 🍻

Yeah, most of the extinct species became extinct before humans were even on the scene. But even for more recent species, we tend to assume that a species going extinct is bad. But there are serious questions to be answered, especially as humans attempt to preserve species that are in danger of disappearing. Humans or no humans, ecologies change, and some species would naturally go extinct, or evolve into different species, whether humans intervened or not. While we might want to save or preserve some species for scientific reasons, there may indeed be species who are no longer fit to survive in a natural environment, and human intervention to save them may cost more than it's worth. Or even prevent their evolution into a more fit species.

In short, we need to go the harder route of considering ecologies as a whole, with all the interactions of the different species in those ecologies.

North American wetland bird thought extinct since the first half of the 20th century, reported sporadic sightings in Florida Georgia and Missouri throughout the last half of the century. A series of videos and photographs surfaced in the mid 00s, capturing what appears to be the Ivory Bill alive in Missouri.

I only mentioned it because I could swear I saw one in the suburbs of Atlanta after a series of storms had driven many non-native species into the area in mid-migration. My inability to identify it, as I've never seen a woodpecker of that size before, led me to pictures of the extinct bird online. It was the closest in plumage, markings, size, and the white bill of course, than any large woodpecker species still alive today.

Coelacanths aren't "simple" they have some pretty advanced features compared to other fish including bearing live young and an electric field sensing organ inside their braincase. The brain stops growing while the fish is young but the skull keeps growing and the extra space is filled by fat tissue and the sensory organ. They also have a weird lung-like buoyancy organ filled with fat that seems to have evolved independently from the air filled swim bladders of ray finned fishes.
